Captain Diego García Villalón, the pilot of the Santiaguillo, brought with him from Peru a clock, probably like this turret clock. De Mérida now begins to use hours and hour increments to describe the passage of time. Courtesy of Rauantiques.

In Part SS, de Mérida describes fighting Mapuche deep within the thick forests to the south of Santiago:  \"When forced to travel through this darkness to seek out and subdue Mapuche forts and armed bands of hostiles, we felt ourselves to be within a colossal wilderness, so dark as to be almost black.  Montesinos referred to this landscape as \"the dark\", a name we all quickly took up, for it described these murky places exactly.\"  Picture:  Forest scene in southern Chile.  Courtesy of Jason and Alexa.
Wood Engraving of Mapuche mother and child. Original Wood Engraving. The Macmillan Company. R. Villarreal Collection.
Forest scene in the land of the Mapuche.  Courtesy of yiyodiazch.
A forest clearing.  Courtesy of chocoli.

Valdivia led a contingent of men to look for a rumored gold mining area north northeast from Santiago and came upon the rich growing area near Quillota in the Río Aconcagua Valley.  Courtesy of paltita.
This is another view of the Aconcagua valley.  Courtesy of winechile.
Located in the Quillota area is the low peak of La Campana, the site of a small gold mine.  Courtesy of carlos.
Google map of the La Campana and Quillota area.
On their way north to find Michimalongo, Valdivia and his troops passed by the small village of Illapel.  Courtesy of francisco.pf.
North of Illapel lies Limari and this area is where the Christians fought Michimalongo and his warriors in a brief but bloody battle.  Courtesy of Juan Bustos.

This is an overhead Google look at the Andacollo copper/gold mine, which lies twenty miles east from Cuquimpu.  The Christians were able extract tons of gold from the area through the years.  It is still a rich store of copper and gold.
The small city of Andacollo lies on the outskirts of the mine.  Courtesy of Retamal.
Captain Juan Bautísta de Pastene arrived on the San Pedro with supplies for the growing town of Santiago in mid-1544. Artist: Alonso de Ovalle.
The anatomy of Captain Pastene's ship, the San Pedro, looked much like this on and above deck.
This mariner's spyglass was a necessity on board any sailing vessel. This one is two feet in length.  R. Villarreal collection.
This nautical compass was likewise a sailing ship necessity.  R. Villarreal collection.
A replica of an astrolabe used by Pastene.  R. Villarreal collection.
In another 100 years or so from Pastene's days, the nautical sextant (pictured) replaced the astrolabe to determine positioning and location.  R. Villarreal collection.
The Santiaguillo and the San Pedro prepare to leave the Valparaíso harbor on the exploration voyage to the south. Artist: Lima de Freitas.
The mate in the foremast nest shouts that an island is off the port side bow.  Captain Pastene named it Isla de San Nicolas de Tolentino.  Artist:  Lima de Freitas.
The San Pedro's ship's mates attend to their duties atop the mizzenmast. Artist: Lima de Freitas.

After leaving Isla Tolentino, the ships encountered hard winds.  Here is how Pastene described it in his journal:   \"September 12, 1544.  Our progress to the S was slowed early on the morning watch as unfavorable head winds blowing lustily at 39°15′S caused me to tack frequently 80 degrees to port and starboard as we beat before the wind.  At mid-day, we were in a full gale that blew with such violence that the San Pedro was almost driven forecastle under until I ordered the sails taken in, which eased the situation considerably.\"  Artist:  Lima de Freitas.
The San Pedro was similar to this 16th century caravel. Courtesy of Alamy.
Captain Valdivia sent Pastene and several men on a month long voyage of discovery south from Valparaíso.  This is the route they followed.  Courtesy of wiki.
This is a Google map of their major discoveries:  Mancera Island, the Río Valdivia, and the site of today's city of Valdivia.
1878 original in-text wood engraving of a Mapuche family.  Creator:  Edward Stanford.  R. Villarreal Collection.
The modern day city of Valdivia.  Courtesy of wiki.
1903 Original halftone print of Valdivia.  Creator: George Philip & Son.  R. Villarreal Collection.
Another dark forest scene typical of the landscape around Valdivia city.  Courtesy of visitchile.
Pastene approaches Isla Santa Maria and claims it for King Phillip. Artist: Reynolds Stone.
Isla Santa Maria lies just to the south of Concepción. Google image.
Captain Pastene and his men head ashore to Isla Santa Maria to barter with the natives. Artist: Lima de Freitas.

An artist's rendering of the Inca Toqui, Michimalongo. Despite his several years of opposition to the Christians, he eventually decided to accept them and entered into an agreement of friendship with Valdivia. Courtesy of memoriachilena.

In February, 1546, Valdivia and sixty horse soldiers journeyed south from Santiago to found new towns and pacify the Mapuche.  This is one of the rivers they crossed, the  Río Maule.  Courtesy of Juan Bustos.
The Río Maule region.  Google Earth image.
Farther south, they crossed the Río Nuble.  Google Earth image.
The landscape near the the Río Nuble.  Courtesy of Patricio Ahumada.
Heavy forested landscape near the Río Nuble.  Courtesy of Pixabay.
1922 Original half-tone print of an Araucanian home structure.  Publisher:  National Geographic.  R. Villarreal Collection.
The Battle of Quilacura took place at night, with the Mapuche hiding in high grass like this.  Courtesy of pexels.
Image of the Quilacura battle site.  Google Earth.
Area near where the Battle of Quilacura took place.  Courtesy of Maria Figueroa.
Following the Battle of Quiiacura, the Christians marched west for the coast near the Río BioBio.  Courtesy of Maly1995
Another photo of the BioBio.  Courtesy of M. Escobar.
An image of the Penco, Concepción area.  Captain Valdivia decided this location would be the future site of a new town. Google Earth.
A modern day view of Concepción.  Courtesy of Alvaro Molina.
The forested landscape to the east of Concepción.  Courtesy of WWF.
The BioBio empties into the Pacific near Penco.  Courtesy of Pencos.
Engraving depicting Valdivia, Villagran, and de Alderete.  Artist unknown.

Captain Valdivia decided to go to Peru to help the Viceroy, Father Pedro de la Gasca, fight an insurrection led by Gonzalo Pizarro. Valdivia destroyed the Pizarro forces in the course of one afternoon at the Battle of Xaquixahuana. This depiction of the skirmish is by an unknown artist.

The new Viceroy of Peru, Pedro de la Gasca, asked Captain Valdivia to help him defeat the uprising against his rule led by Gonzalo Pizarro. This painting depicts Spanish fighting Spanish at the Battle of Xaquixahuana. Artist: Everett Gee Jackson.
Valdivia and his men defeated Pizarro, and de la Gasca had Pizarro and his chief captain, Carbajal, beheaded. Pizarro's head is on the right. Artist: Everett Gee Jackson.
Viceroy de la Gasca ponders the appointment of Valdivia as the Governor of Chile. Artist: Lima de Freitas.
The Christians were attacked by 2,000 Mapuche at the Río Nivequeten (today's Laja) and killed 1,200 of them.  Google Earth image.
Today's river.  Courtesy of umdiewelt.
The Río Nivequeten (today's Laja) merges with the Bio-Bio. 1895 Original Print by Jacques Reclus, Hachette & Co. R. Villarreal Collection.

The Battle of the Río Andalién pitted 200 Christian soldiers against 20,000 Mapuche that began around midnight.  It continued for several hours until, after daybreak, the Spanish were able to rout the hostiles by killing more than 2,000.  Google image.
A picture of today's river.  Courtesy of Contreras.
The Battle of Andalién took place at the constricted area between the Río (out of sight to the left) and this small lake, Laguna Pineda.  Courtesy of GOCHILE.

The Battle of Penco was an assault upon the Fortress of Penco by an estimated 40,000 Mapuche led by the Mapuche toquis, Ainavillo and Colo-Colo.  After several hours, the Spanish routed the Indian forces, killing thousands.  Google image.
This is an artist's rendering of an early Spanish fort in Chile.  Artist unknown.
The view east of the Concepción and Penco region.  Google Earth image.
The San Pedro and Santiaguillo depart the Valparaíso roads for Concepción with fruit, vegetables, pigs, construction supplies, and workers for the new town. Artist: Lima de Freitas.
Valdivia founded Concepción de María Purísima del Nuevo Extremo on October 5 of 1550.  This is what the city looks like today.  Courtesy of HELLOCHILE.
Captain Pastene founded Isla Santa Maria south of Concepción and west of Arauco in 1550.  The Spanish traded for food with the islanders.  Today it has a population of 2,200.  Google image.
A modern day view of Isla Santa Maria. The island is the place where the Herman Melville novel Benito Cereno takes place. Courtesy of GOCHILE.
Captene Pastene discovered this island in 1555 and named it Isla de San Nicolas de Tolentino.  Google image.

Isla San Nicolas was renamed Isla Mocha in the late 16th century.  The waters off the island are noted as the home of a famous 19th century sperm whale, Mocha Dick as depicted by American explorer and author Jeremiah N. Reynolds who published an account, \"Mocha Dick: Or The White Whale of the Pacific.\"  Herman Melville used this for his novel, Moby Dick.  Courtesy of TRAVELCHILE.

In September of 1550, De Mérida was sent back to Santiago to work on Cabildo matters. There, he greeted his new son, Vicente de Mérida de Santiago born a month before. He was named after Pedro’s friend, Vicente Montesinos. Courtesy of TRAVELSA.
A bust of the Mapuche toqui, Lautaro.

Founded March 16 of 1551, the original site of La Imperial was destroyed several times through the years by the Mapuche and was relocated twelve miles east and named New Imperial.  The original town site has been re-founded as Carahue.  Google image.
La Imperial, renamed Carahue, today has 25,000 citizens.  Courtesy of ELMOSTRADOR.
Although this sailing ship is from a later century, it provides a likeness of the San Pedro, captained by Juan Bautísta de Pastene. Artist: Geoffrey Ingleton.
Again, this is a later vessel, but it is similar to the Santiaguillo, piloted by Captain Diego García Villalón. Artist: Geoffrey Ingleton.
Valdivia founded La Imperial on March 16, 1551.  Google image.
Governor Valdivia established Fortress Valdivia on February 9, 1552 and named the town around it Santa Maria la Blanca de Valdivia.  Google Earth image.
The present day city of Valdivia.  Courtesy of TRIPADVISOR.
A forest scene on the outskirts of Valdivia.  The Christians skirmished with Mapuche near this area.  Courtesy of GO CHILE.

On February 19 of 1552, Captain Gerónimo de Alderete performed the foundation ceremony for Santa María Magdalena de Villarrica.  It lies 65 miles northeast from Valdivia on the shores of Lago Villarrica.  Volcan Villarrica sits to the east.  Google image.
Volcan Villarrica (9,380') is east of the city 15 miles away.  Courtesy of TripAdvisor.

De Mérida, back in Santiago with Valdivia for a brief visit, adopts with his wife, Pilca Huaca, an abandoned baby girl. They name her Inés de Mérida de Santiago de Chile after their friend, Inés de Suárez.  Courtesy of GoChile.

Lautaro asked Valdivia's permission on the march south to leave the column to pick this flower with medicinal properties. With no one to watch him, he escaped and joined his Mapuche brethren.  Courtesy of NatMed.
A Mapuche warrior stares from his dark jungle hiding place as he waits for unsuspecting Christians.  Artist:  Robert Shore.
In October of 1553, the Christians founded forts at Tucapel, Puren, and Los Confines.  Google image.
Los Confines today  (now known as Angol). Valdivia founded a fort here in October of 1553.  Courtesy of TripAdvisor.
Today's Fort Purén. On October 25 of 1553, Captain Juan Gómez de Almagro founded the fort of Purén. Courtesy of ccpoChile.
Another view of Fort Purén.  Courtesy of Vidal.
Drawing of an unidentified Arauco war battle. Artist: de Bibar.

Lautaro was a Mapuche youth who tricked Valdivia into thinking that he was on the side of the Christians in the war with the Mapuche.  Valdivia, impressed by him, took him on as his \"page.\"  Courtesy of subercaseaux.
Caupolican was one of the important Mapuche toqui's in the Arauco Wars against the Christians. Courtesy of Nicanor.
Colo-Colo was another toqui of prominence in the Wars. Statue resides at the Estadio Monumental in Santiago, Chile.
Lautaro escaped from the Christians in late 1552 and went into battle training under the tutelage of Caupolican and Colo-Colo.  Courtesy of biographiadechile.

On his way to join up with Valdivia at Tucapel, de Almagro was ambushed by Colo-Colo at today's Contulmo and was delayed by one day from the meeting, thus allowing the Mapuche to slaughter Valdivia and his men.   Courtesy of GoChile.
An artist's rendition of the possible last moments of Governor Valdivia and his men at the Battle of Tucapel on December 25 of 1553. Courtesy of ghconcepcion.

Another depiction of the Battle of Tucapel.  Since there were no survivors, we don't know exactly all that happened, other than the Mapuche chopped up the bodies, roasted some of the body parts, and \"gorged upon them.\" Courtesy of  commons.wikipedia.
Captain Pastene and the San Pedro head north from Valdivia to Concepción with men wounded in battles with the Mapuche after the disaster at Tucapel. Artist: Lima de Freitas.
The San Pedro sails from Concepción north to Valparaíso. On board are the men injured in the Mapuche battles, including de Mérida with his crippling ankle injury. Artist: Reynolds Stone.
Map showing the extent of the Inca Empire at the time of the Conquest. Artist: Everett Lee Jackson.

An early map of Panamá. Captains Francisco Pizarro and Diego de Almagro sailed from Panamá city on several expeditions to the south from 1522-1532 in search of the golden kingdom of the Inca. De Mérida uses the ship journals of Pilot-Captain Juan Bautísta de Pastene to re-create these dangerous and historic expeditions. Antique print by Arnoldus Montanus, published in Amsterdam by Jacob van Meurs in 1671. \"The New and Unknown World: or Description of America and the Southland.\" R. Villarreal Collection.

Pedro de Mérida and Vicente Montesinos arrived in Peru with Captain Hernán de Soto in 1532. De Mérida will tell of the fall of the Incas in his three letters to the King. Antique print, titled: Peru, by Arnoldus Montanus, published in Amsterdam by Jacob van Meurs in 1671. \"The New and Unknown World: or Description of America and the Southland.\" R. Villarreal Collection.

Pizarro: Captain Francisco Pizarro (1471-1541) partnered with Captain Diego de Almagro (1475-1538) to discover the location of the Inca Empire. Their friendship later turned to enmity. Almagro was executed by Pizarro and Pizarro was slain by Almagro's son, Almagro the Younger. Courtesy of Amable-Paul Coutan, 1835 (Pizarro).

Almagro: Captain Francisco Pizarro (1471-1541) partnered with Captain Diego de Almagro (1475-1538) to discover the location of the Inca Empire. Their friendship later turned to enmity. Almagro was executed by Pizarro and Pizarro was slain by Almagro's son, Almagro the Younger. Courtesy of Domingo Mesa (Almagro).

In November of 1524, Captains Pizarro and Almagro prepare in the harbor of Panamá City for their first voyage of discovery to look for the natives of a country called \"Biru\" or \"Piru\". Artist: Lima de Freitas.
The anatomy of the ships sailed by Captains Ruíz, Pastene, and Grijalva looked much like this above and below decks.

An astrolabe is an elaborate inclinometer historically used by astronomers and navigators to measure the inclined position in the sky of a celestial body, day or night. For its usage, see the next image.

In order to use the astrolabe, the navigator held the instrument by the ring at the top. This caused it to remain in a vertical plane. The alidade was aligned to point at the object and the altitude was read off the outer degree scale.

Captains Pizarro and Almagro sailed south from Panamá City on their three expeditions from 1524 to 1532 to find the fabled kingdom of \"Birú\". The Isle of Pearls, a vital storage area for the expeditions, lies several miles to the south. Google Earth image.

The captain of the ship carrying Captain Almagro and his men on the first voyage was Juan de Grijalva. This captain had mapped the eastern coast of Mexico for Hernán Cortés several years before. It is not known who piloted Pizarro's vessel. Artist unknown.

Captain Juan Bautista de Pastene was one of the Captain-pilots who transported the Captains Pizarro, Almagro, and their men from Panamá to various locations on the western coast of South America in search of the Inca from 1524 to 1532.  Artist: Alonso de Ovalle.
Captain Bartolomé Ruiz started his career as a pilot for Christopher Columbus and later joined Francisco Pizarro and Diego de Almagro as their chief pilot in the conquest of Peru. Artist unknown.

The Peru/Humboldt Current extends from southern Chile (-45th parallel south) to northern Peru (-4th parallel south). Ships sailing south down the western shores of South America had to tack continually in order to make progress.  When returning north, the Current was in their favor.

The westerlies are the prevailing winds in the middle latitudes. These winds blow from west to east and are from the southwest in the Northern Hemisphere and from the northwest in the Southern. The trade winds, or trades, are the prevailing easterly winds near the equator. They blow from the northeast in the Northern Hemisphere and from the southeast in the Southern. Ship pilots had to sail against them or with them when they traveled north or south.
On the first voyage south in 1524, Pizarro came upon a village of cannibals. When they fled, he and his men took the many gold and silver objects back to their ship. Artist: Geoffrey C. Ingleton.
On his voyage south in search of Pizarro in 1525, Almagro sailed in the San Cristóbal, piloted by the famed and noteworthy Pilot-Captain, Juan de Grijalva. Artist: Lima de Freitas.

In the search for Pizarro, Almagro and his men put in here at Puerto Quemado (today's Nuqui, Columbia). They were attacked by the natives and driven back to the San Cristóbal. They returned the next morning to give battle and, although they routed the Indians, Almagro suffered a stone to the left side of his head that caused a permanent loss of sight in that eye. Artist: Lima de Freitas.
This is the area of Puerto Quemado, where Almagro lost sight in his left eye in a fight with local Indians. Today this is the resort beach area of Nuqui, Colombia. Courtesy of ColoTravel.
Almagro and Grijalva in the San Cristóbal return to Panamá City. Artist: Reynolds Stone.

The San Sebastián, with Captain Ruiz in command, sails from Panamá city in 1526 with Captain Pizarro and his men on their second expedition south to search for the golden land of the Inca. Captain Pastene, piloting the Santa Maria de la Consolación, (not in view), follows behind with Captain Almagro and his men. Artist: Reynolds Stone.
Captain Pastene and his men on the deck of the Consolación. Artist: Lima de Freitas.
The Consolación follows behind the San Sebastián (not in view). Artist: Reynolds Stone.

On Isla Gallo, Pizarro confronted a mutiny among his men. He drew a line in the sand and challenged those who wanted to continue to step across it. Thirteen ultimately did so and became known as the \"Famous Thirteen.\" Artist: Juan Lipiani.
Isla Gallo. Google Earth.
A local native, Juanita, stands at the location where Pizarro drew his line in the sand on Isla Gallo. National Geographic.
Because of the harsh conditions on Isla Gallo, Pizarro and the Thirteen built a small boat and sailed to the nearby Isla Gorgona.

Natives of Tumbez row out to greet Pizarro and his men in the San Sebastián. One of their number is the Orejón, an Inca noble of the town. Artist: Everett Gee Jackson. Also, see painting P7.1 for a rendering of this noble.
The natives of Tumbez welcome the San Sebastián. Artist: Geoffrey C. Ingleton.
Pizarro sent Pedro de Candía and Alonzo de Molina to visit the townspeople of Tumbez and learn more of their customs, the fortress, and the blue temple (see P. 7.2). Artist: Lima de Freitas.
Pizarro's men barter with the Tumbez natives, who were very friendly and welcoming.  Artist:  Lima de Freitas.
Google Earth image of Tumbez and the surrounding country.
Leaving Tumbez, Pizarro sailed south in the San Sebastián and visited several villages on the coast. Artist: Geoffrey C. Ingleton.

While Pizarro and his men marched along the coast towards Tumbez, they stopped at a place he named Puerto Viejo. Captain-Pilot Ruíz in the San Sebastián and Pilot Tafur in the Consolación. came with supplies and men to reinforce him and stopped at the Puerto. Lieutenant Vicente Montesinos was one of the fifty-six new men. Artist: Geoffrey C. Ingleton.
Captain Ruíz in the San Sebastián ferries men from the mainland to Isla Puná. Artist: Reynolds Stone.
Captain Pastene in Santiaguillo nears Isla Puná with Captain Hernando de Soto and the men he recruited on board, including Pedro de Mérida. Artist: Reynolds Stone.
The flames appearing at the mast heads are known as \"corpo santo,\" or, \"holy body.\" This is the term Spanish sailors of the time called it. Today, we know it as St. Elmo’s fire. Artist unknown.

The fire at the stern of the Santiaguillo is another instance of a corpo santo. It's a weather event created by an electrical discharge from a sharp or pointed object in a strong electric field, such as that generated by thunderstorms. Artist: Max de Narisouty.
Captain Hernando de Soto. After he left Peru in 1535, he journeyed to Florida, moved west, and founded the Mississippi River. He died on its banks on May 21, 1542. Artist: Lambert A. Wilmer.
A stylized rendering of Captain Hernando de Soto by Everett Gee Jackson.
In February of 1532, Pizarro and his men are transported from Isla Puná to Tumbez. Artist: Reynolds Stone.
The pilots and ships carrying the men to Tumbez were Captain-Pilot Ruíz in the San Sebastián, Captain-Pilot Pastene in the Santiaguillo, and Pilot Tafur in the Consolación. Artist: Lima de Freitas.
Governor Pizarro points to Tumbez and where he wants to land and disembark. Artist: Lima de Freitas.

The Inca Empire ranged north from Cusco to the towns of Pasto and Quito. Eighty miles south of Quito is the famed mountain of Chimborazo (20,702 feet), a peak the Inca respected because of the mountain gods that resided there. The Inca civil war was caused by Atahuallpa seeking to overthrow his brother, Huascar, and claim the Empire for his own. His leading generals were Quizquiz, Chalicuchima, and Rumiñavi. In April of 1532, Quizquiz and his men led the armies of Atahuallpa to victory at the battles of Mullihambato, Chimborazo, and Quipaipan. The Battle of Chimborazo took place near the peak. This is a wood engraving by the first man to ascend Chimborazo in January of 1880, Edward Whymper. This is called today the Whymper Ridge. R. Villarreal Collection.
A Whymper engraving of the summit of Chimborazo. R. Villarreal Collection.
The Whymper Ridge is to the right with the Chimborazo summit behind. The author climbed to the top in March of 1988. R. Villarreal Collection.

The author, before ascending the peak, stands on the outskirts of the small town of Guarandas to the west from Chimborazo in the distance. This area is where the Battle of Chimborazo was fought. R. Villarreal Collection.

Governor Pizarro founded San Miguel de Piura on 24 September of 1532. It served as the \"jump-off\" point for his journey into the Andes in the east to search for the High Inca, Atahuallpa. Courtesy of PERUTRAVEL.

These are the Alfonsine Tables that Pastene used to frighten the cannibals he encountered on the way back to Panamá with his prediction of a solar eclipse. They were a set of astronomical data that enabled calculation of eclipses for any given time based on the Ptolemaic Theory. Calculated in 1252, they were the best astronomical tables available, until the work of Nicolaus Copernicus superseded them in the 1550’s.

Pizarro sent Hernando de Soto and his men, including de Mérida, on a ride through near by towns in the Andes, Ayabaca, Caxas, and Huancabamba, in search of the whereabouts of Atahuallpa. Pizarro and his men waited in Zarán (present-day name is Serran). Google Earth.

Today's Ayabaca, which sits at 8,900' in elevation. Some of de Soto's men were affected by the altitude. Martín gave them coca leaves to ease the effects. Coca is still used today in the Andes for the same purpose. Courtesy of GOPERU.
In Huancabamba at 6,400', de Soto learned more as to the location of Atahuallpa and his army. Courtesy of Travel Peru.
Another picture of Huancabamba. Courtesy of R. Viente.

De Mérida explains to the King the elaborate and efficient road system of the Inca. This is a high level overview of the important royal roads. Courtesy of Victor W. von Hagen in his, <u>The Royal Road of the Inca.</u>
This is von Hagen's depiction of the roads of the northern empire.
This is von Hagen's presentation of the royal Inca roads of the central empire.
Von Hagen's drawing of the southern Inca roads.
A stylized rendering of a chasqui runner. Artist: Everett Gee Jackson.
Qunchamarka tambo, a large storage structure on the Inca road to Machu Picchu. Courtesy of G. Robertson.
A fine example of a knotted quipu. Only those trained for years in their use could construct or interpret them. Courtesy of PERUARTI.

Viracocha. The villagers in the Andean towns visited by de Soto and his men as they searched for a representative of the Lord High Inca, Atahuallpa, hailed them as Viracochas. Viracocha was the the name they gave to the creator of all things in this world. Artist: Unknown.
Viracocha. Artist: Poma de Ayala.
Inti, the sun god. On the gold drinking vessel Atahuallpa sent Pizarro, the Inti was carved on its side. Also, the Inti is displayed on the national flag of Peru. Artist: Bernardo de Tagli.
Pachacuti Inca pays homage to the Inti. Artist: Martin de Murua.
The silver drinking fountain given Pizarro was engraved with the image of the moon goddess, Mama Quilla.
Father de Segovia, who accompanied de Soto in the search for Atahuallpa's envoy, blesses villagers in Caxas. Artist: Everett Gee Jackson.

On the march to Caxamalca to meet Atahuallpa, Pizarro's force of 170 men included three arquebusiers. The arquebus was an early muzzle-loaded firearm used in the 15th to 17th centuries. In distinction from its predecessor, the hand cannon, it had a matchlock. Courtesy pirates.missledine.com.
Pizarro had two falconets, small cannon, as part of his armament. Depiction of a falconet in action. Artist: Everett Gee Jackson.

The falconet, or falcon, was a light cannon developed in the late 15th century. The barrel was four feet long, had a caliber of 5 cm, and weighed 176 lb. It used .5 pounds of black powder to fire a 1 pound round shot at a maximum range of approximately 5,000 feet.
On the way to meet the Lord High Inca, Pizarro and his men marched from Zarán to Motupe, then through Sicán to La Ramada, where they rested for several days. Google Earth image.
A stylized rendering of Governor Francisco Pizarro. Artist: Everett Gee Jackson.
Pizarro and his men, now in the Andes on their way to Caxamalco (Cajamarca), began to see the high flying condor. Courtesy of SV Calpso.
The journey took them through Batán Grande, once a city of the Sicán Culture of the 8th-12th century A.D. Here are some of the ruins still standing. Courtesy of Grande Tours.
Map showing the terrain Pizarro and his men passed over. Google Earth.
A rendering of the terrain encountered on the journey to Caxamalco. Artist: Edward Bawden.
Caption: Pizarro and his men reached Ciudad Llama after a two day effort and a rise of 7,000 feet in elevation. Today's village has 3,000 inhabitants. Courtesy of Trip Advisor.
The Spaniards entered Chota, elevation 7,000 feet, to welcoming villagers hailing them as \"viracochas\" (gods). The city today has 47,000 citizens. Courtesy of TIENDEO.PE.
The next town they came to, again with welcoming villagers, was Bambamarca, at 8,400 feet. Courtesy of Travel Peru.

On November 14 of 1532, Pizarro and his men looked down upon the beautiful city of Caxamalca (Cajamarca), where Atahuallpa awaited their arrival. Its elevation is 8,900 feet and has a population of 201,000. Courtesy of Travel Peru.

Caxamalca and Ba&ntildeos. Caption: The city of Caxamalca (known as Cajamarca today). The Ba&ntildeos del Inca are 3 1/2 miles to the east of the city down the straight Avenida Atahuallpa. Google image.
In 1533, Pizarro founded the first Catholic Church in Peru here in Cajamarca and named it San Francisco. Courtesy of Wikimedia.
One section of the Ba&ntildeos del Inca. Tourists today still enjoy the warm waters. Courtesy of Gregor Ludwig.
The straight thoroughfare Avenida Attahuallpa connects Cajamarca with the Inca Baths. Courtesy of BICICS.

Hernando Pizarro and Hernando de Soto, with twenty men, were sent by Francisco Pizarro to visit Atahuallpa at the baths. The Lord Inca was fascinated by their horses and asked to see what they could do. De Soto shows him with this menacing gesture. Notice that the Lord Inca is completely unfazed. Courtesy of Louis S. Glanzman.
Hernando Pizarro was Francisco's \"right hand man.\" A capable soldier, he often tortured Indians to obtain information from them. Courtesy of Everett Gee Jackson.
Atahuallpa is carried in his litter on the shoulders of eighty Indians on his way to meet Governor Pizarro. Courtesy of Edward Bawden.

This is Francisco de Xerez, the secretary to Francisco Pizarro. He wrote, \"A true Account of the Province of Cusco.\" He broke his leg in mid-1533, after the capture of Atahuallpa, and returned to Spain. Artist: Lima de Freitas.
A jumbled scene depicting the slaughter of the Peruvians during the seizure of Atahuallpa. Artist: Edward Bawden.
Father Valverde celebrates the capture of the Lord High Inca. Artist unknown.
Pizarro meets Atahuallpa, painted by the obscure but noteworthy Poma de Ayala.
This is one of the rooms in Cajamarca, Peru,  used to house the gold and silver objects the Incas gave Pizarro and the Spaniards to purchase Atahuallpa's release. Courtesy of A. Velasco.
The Incas paid the Lord Inca's ransom with objects like this one. This is a gold depiction of the Inca sun god, Inti, and resides in the Bogota Gold Museum. Courtesy of Museum.
Another object that would have been part of the ransom. Courtesy of Bogota Gold Museum.
A golden head like this one most likely was part of the ransom. Courtesy of Bogota Gold Museum.
These are two gold cups like those furnish to the Spaniards for Atahuallpa's ransom. Courtesy of the Lima Gold Museum.
More golden cups for the ransom. Courtesy of the Lima Gold Museum.
Another cup of gold for the ransom. Courtesy of the Lima Gold Museum.

Captain Pastene in his daily log of the voyage from Panama to San Miguel, Peru, with Captain Almagro and his men, tells of seeing a ghost ship, also known as a phantom ship. This is a vessel with no living crew aboard; it may be a ghostly vessel in folklore or fiction, such as the Flying Dutchman, or a real derelict found adrift with its crew missing or dead, like the Mary Celeste. Courtesy of Albert Pinkham Ryder.
Another phantom ship image.  Artist unknown.
These phantoms are different than the others in that they lie suspended in the air.  Courtesy of Frank R. Stockton.

According to Chilean legend, the Caleuche is a large ship sailing the seas around Chiloé (a small island off the coast of Chile) at night. The Caleuche is said to be a being who is conscious and sentient. The ship appears as a beautiful and bright white sailing ship, with 3 masts of 5 sails each, always full of lights and with the sounds of a party on board, but quickly disappears again, leaving no evidence of its presence. The ghost ship is also known to be able to navigate under water, just like another well known ghost ship, the Flying Dutchman. Courtesy of Nightwatch.
The Santiaguillo, San Cristobal, and San Sebastian, struggle, as they endure a heavy storm off the coast of southern Ecuador. Artist: Lima de Freitas.

On Hernando Pizarro's march to Pachacamac, he and his men came upon two finely constructed bridges at the town of Coronga. The foot soldiers used one bridge and the horse soldiers the other. Artist: Edward Bawden

Hernando Pizarro and his band of twenty horse soldiers were sent by Francisco Pizarro to the coastal city of Pachacamac to take possession of the gold there as part of the ransom of Atahuallpa. On the way, they passed the fortress of Paramonga, an important city of the former Kingdom of Chimor during the late Intermediate Period (AD 1200 to 1400). Its capital was the metropolis of Chan Chan. Artist: Charles Weiner.
This is today's fortress of Paramonga. Its ruins are impressive. Courtesy of TravelPeru.

Pachacamac ruins. Pachacamac is an archaeological site 25 miles southeast of Lima, Peru in the Valley of the Lurin River. The site was first settled around A.D. 200 and was named after the \"Earth Maker\" creator god Pachas Kamac. Courtesy of MysteryPeru.

Pacha Kamaq ('Earth-Maker') was considered the creator god by the people who lived in coastal Peru before the Inca conquest. The Inca added him to their pantheon, but he was never an equal of Viracocha, whom they viewed as the lord of all creation. Artist: Everett Gee Jackson.
Another part of the extensive ruins of Pachacamac. Courtesy of Travel Peru.
Another part of the Pachacamac ruins. Courtesy of BANKEDUP.
More ruins. When my wife and I adopted our first daughter in Cusco in 1978, we toured the Pachacamac ruins. R. Villarreal Collection.
This is another view of Pachacamac ruins. R. Villarreal Collection.

While at Pachacamac, Hernando Pizarro learned that the warrior chief, Chalicuchima, was camped near Xauxa (today's Jauja) with great quantities of gold and silver for Atahuallpa's ransom. He decided to meet him and escort the gold shipment to Caxamalca. Google Earth image.

In mid-March of 1533 on the way to Xauxa to meet with Chalicuchima, the Spaniards passed through the village of Tarma. Their horses badly needed shoes. Fortunately there were several metal smiths in the town and they were able to melt the silver from Pachacamac and shape it into shoes. Drawing courtesy of William Lewis Herndon.
Today's Tarma. Courtesy of OTTOCAROTTO.
Jauja's main drag, Alameda Clodoaldo. Courtesy of Della Bayona.
Pizarro sent three men from Caxamalca to visit Cusco. Their disgraceful conduct is told by de Mérida. This is a 1598 engraving of the sacred city. Artist: Sebastian Munster. R. Villarreal Collection.

Since Cusco in the Inca language means \"navel,\" the lands of its kingdom were reached by four roads (pictured) beginning at the large square, the center of the Inca world. The region to the north to Quito was called Chinchaysuyu, with the royal road there named accordingly. The way to the southern area of Chile was called the Collasuysu. The Antisuyu road bore east to the lower valleys of the Amazon region. And the Contisuyu thoroughfare ran west to the lower valleys along the Pacific coast.
This is the beginning of the Chinchaysuyu road as it leaves the main plaza of Cusco for the north to Quito. R. Villarreal Collection.
The Coricancha, or Temple of the Sun (the Inti). Courtesy of Diego Delso.
This is the main square of Cusco, now known as the Plaza de Armas.  Courtesy of Barbara Weibel.
The Inca Fortress of Sacsayhuaman sits on a hill above the sacred city. Courtesy of PeruTravel.
To melt Atahuallpa's gold and silver ransom pieces, it took nine furnaces burning around the clock for four days. Artist: Everett Gee Jackson.
Atahuallpa, the Lord High Inca.  Artist: Everett Gee Jackson.

De Mérida tells of a comet appearing in the sky in June of 1533. A comet astronomers have called 1533 (M1) was visible on June 27, 1533, and remained so for 83 days. Xerez mentions it in his, \"Report\", and Cieza de Leone remarks upon it also in his, \"Chronicle\", Third Part, Ch.65.

Governor Francisco Pizarro sent his brother, Hernando, to Spain to tell the King and his court of the activities in the land of Peru. Here he departs on the Santiaguillo, with Captain Pastene as pilot, for Panamá. Artist: Hans Alexander Mueller.
The men return from replenishing their food stores. Artist: Hans Alexander Mueller.
The Santiaguillo sails full sheets to the wind. Artist: Geoffrey C. Ingleton.

At the hour of Vespers on the 26th of July, Pizarro led the men to the city square lit by torch-light, where a couch had been placed at its center. Father Valverde accompanied the lord Inca and made the sign of the cross over him several times. Atahuallpa was told to sit, and one of our men placed a rope about his neck. While Fathers de Pedraza and de Segovia led us in the recitation of the Holy Creed, Atahuallpa was swiftly strangled. The priests said prayers over him in a final gesture to acknowledge his conversion to our Holy Faith. The Governor then ordered his body left in the square until the morrow. Artist: Everett Gee Jackson.
On the way to Cusco from Xauxa, the Spaniards had to cross several rivers. Bridges like this one could not accommodate the horses and men so they had to ford them instead. Courtesy of howabouthat.

Also on the way to Cusco, they encountered several Inca tampus, or tambos, buildings that contained clothing and and other Inca army accessories. 1875 wood engraving of and Inca tampu. Artist: Edouardo Riou. Publisher: Scribner Armstrong.
This is the terrain over which the Spanish fought the Incas on their way to capture Cusco.

A royal prince by the name of Manco entered the Spanish camp at Xaquixahuana (today's town of Anta, twenty miles north from Cusco), and declared himself a son of the deceased Lord High Inca, Huayna Capac. Pizarro was impressed by his bearing and his royal lineage. Artist: Everett Gee Jackson.
Suspected of collusion with the Inca general, Quizquiz in Cusco to annihilate the Christians, Pizarro has Chalicuchima burned alive. Artist: Poma de Ayala.
Chalicuchima could have become a Christian, like Atahuallpa, and died by the garrote, but he refused and thus was burned to death. Artist: Edward Bawden.
Today's Anta, the Xaquixahuana of Inca days, with the small church still in service. Courtesy of Ojeda Flores.
Pizarro and his men look down upon Cusco prior to entering the sacred city. Antique print of Cusco by Arnoldus Montanus, 1671. R Villarreal Collection.

The Crown of Castile flag was the first European symbol to arrive in the New World. Two flag bearers rode behind the trumpeters, with Pizarro and his troops behind them, as they rode into Cusco on Wednesday, November 15 of 1533. Courtesy of Wikipedia.
The day after the conquistadors entered Cusco on November 15 of 1533, Governor Pizarro crowned Manco as the new Lord Inca. Artist: Poma de Ayala.
Map depicting Cusco before the Spanish invasion. Courtesy of John Hemming, \"The Conquest of the Incas\".

This is today's Santo Domingo church. Its foundation is that of the Inca temple of Coricancha dedicated to the Inca sun god, Inti. The Coricancha was dismantled in the 17th century and the church was built upon the remaining foundation. R. Villarreal Collection.

The Coricancha, or the Inca Temple of the Sun dedicated to Inti, is located in the Inca capital of Cusco. Mostly destroyed after the 16th century war with the Spanish conquistadors, much of its stonework forms the present-day foundation of the Santo Domingo Convent. Courtesy of Guillermo Acahuasi.

The Inca fortress of Sacsayhuaman sits on a hill on the northern border of Cusco. The Spanish, in a furious battle over several days, were finally able to overcome General Quizquiz and his warriors and take possession of it. R. Villarreal Collection.
A close-up view of the massive walls of Sacsayhuaman. Courtesy of Diego Delso.
Father de Segovia teaches the sacred word to the natives of Cusco. Artist: Jean Charlot.
Outside the sacred city of Cusco, Father de Segovia travels to nearby villages to spread the word.

A ruthless Mexico conquistador, Pedro de Alvarado, learned of the great riches of gold and silver in Quito and decided to conquer it, without the King's permission. Besides, this land was part of the purview of Francisco Pizarro. He set off from Guatemala in early 1534 and sailed with his 500 men to Guayaquil and began his march inland to take the city. Image courtesy of wikicommons.

The native guides deserted Alvarado and he was forced to try to find his way through the mountains to find Quito. This is the view east. His route was the high  pass between the Volcan Carihuairazo and Chimborazo, where he lost 85 of his men to the cold. Google Earth image.
Captain Sebastián de Belalcázar was sent by Pizarro to intercept Alvarado and/or reach Quito before he did. Artist: Unknown.
On his march north, Belalcázar and his men were attacked by Quitan troops near the Laguna Colta and drove the enemy north. Google Earth image.

This is the view north from Laguna Colta with Chimborazo fifteen miles to the north. Courtesy of Empelotas. A Christian horseman named it Laguna de la Luna since it mirrored the moon’s light at night upon its calm surface. Courtesy of Empelotas.
The Spanish saw this view of Chimborazo's eastern slopes as they marched north to Quito. Courtesy of Loren McIntyre.
This map shows the routes of Captain Pedro de Alvarado, the intruder from the north, and that of Captain Sebastián de Belalcázar, as they marched north to Quito. Courtesy of John Hemming.
On the way to Quito, fierce Cañari warriors led by their leader, Omaza, joined Captain Belalcázar and his men to assist in the fight against the Quitan warriors. Artist unknown.
Earth image of the route from Latacunga to Quito.
An 1805 map of the Inca town of Quito. Artist: Juan Pio Montufar.
Another painting of Quito, this from the mid-18th century. Artist: Miguel de Santiago

Two days before Captain Belalcázar and his men reached Quito and attacked it, the Inca general, Rumiñavi, ordered his men to loot the city of all its gold and silver. Here the general is conveyed in his litter over the Río Guayllabamba as he retreats north. Artist: Jean Charlot.
Another painting of Quito, this one dated 1850. Artist: Rafael Salas.

Governor Pizarro founded the City of Kings on January 18 of 1535, the capital city in the new land of Peru. The name bestowed upon it Pizarro chose in recognition that this day celebrated the feast day of the Epiphany, the day when the three kings visited the Christ child in his manger. Within a few years the name of Lima took its place. Artist unknown.
An engraving of Lima city. Artist: Poma de Ayala.
1846 painting of Lima Cathedral. Artist: unknown.

Pilot-Captain Juan Bautista Pastene in the Santiaguillo, Pilot-Captain Diego García Villalón in the Consolación, and Pilot-Captain Juan Tafur in the San Sebastián, sailed from Panamá in late October, 1535 with food and supplies for Francisco Pizarro and his men. On board was Hernando Pizarro who was returning from Spain on a visit with the King. Here men from the San Sebastián go ashore to barter with natives for food and water. Artist: Geoffrey Ingleton.
The Consolación beats to windward on the way south. Artist: Hans Mueller.
The San Sebastián sails full sheets to the wind. Artist: Geoffrey Ingleton.
The Santiaguillo off the coast of Ecuador. Artist: Millard Sheets.
The three ships bear south. Artist: Lima de Freitas.
The Consolación passes by Isla Santa Clara west of Guayaquil. Artist: Millard Sheets.
The San Sebastián is almost swamped by waves in a heavy storm south of Santa Clara. Artist: Millard Sheets.
St. Elmo's fire, also known as corpo santo, lights up the spars and rigging of the Santiaguillo. Artist: Unknown.
St. Elmo's fire also appears above the deck of the San Sebastián. Artist: Unknown.
Corpo santo is also in the rigging and trucks of the Consolación. Artist: greencanticle.
The three ships sail west of Tumbez on their way to Peru. Artist: Lima de Freitas.
The ships battle another storm off the shores of Peru. Artist: Lima de Freitas.
The Santiaguillo approaches Lima's port of Callao in mid-December of 1535. Artist: Millard Sheets.

Hernando Pizarro sent his brother, Juan, and seventy horse to confront Manco Inca in the Yucay Valley, north of Cusco. The Christians were surprised when the Inca hordes on the slopes above rolled large boulders down upon them. Artist: Edward Bawden.

By early May of 1536, Manco Inca and 200,000 Inca troops had surrounded Cusco and the 190 Spanish inside. Manco decided to burn the sacred city to force the Christians into the open so that his warriors could butcher them. Artist: Poma de Ayala.
Another depiction of Manco's troops burning Cusco, the capital city. Artist: Edward Bawden.
This is the site of the water tower, the Muyumarca, which was located inside the Fortress. Courtesy of Diego Delso.
The serrated northeastern walls of Sacsayhuaman. Courtesy of Diego Delso.
Depiction of the battle for Fortress Sacsayhuaman. Artist: Unknown.
Massive Fortress wall stones. R. Villarreal Collection.
The northern wall of the Fortress. Courtesy of Diego Delso.
Another view of the northeastern walls of the Fortress. R. Villarreal Collection.
View of the walls near the water tower. R. Villarreal Collection.

Manco Inca sent an adept general by the name of Quizo Yupanqui to do battle with the forces Francisco Pizarro sent from Lima to bolster the Spanish troops in Cusco. These are some of the towns where Quizo annihilated the Spanish. During two months, he and his warriors killed four Christian captains, two hundred men, and ninety horses. This is an Earth image of the towns where the battles occurred.
Near Ayacucho, general Quizo and his men slew many Christians. Courtesy of TravelPeru.
Huaytara was also a town near which Quizo and his warriors wiped out more Spanish forces. Courtesy of toquesonmoto.
Vilcashuaman was the town near which the Spanish were wiped out. Courtesy of blueskylimit.
Caption: Xauxa (today's Jauja) was one more defeat of the Christians. Courtesy of Wiki.
Quizo and his warriors attack Francisco Pizarro and his men in the new city of Lima. Courtesy of LISTVERSE.
Quizo camped out on the hill of San Cristobal to avoid the maneuverability of the Spanish horses. Courtesy of Valladares.
General Quizo is cornered by the Spanish and executed. Courtesy of Wiki.
In their attack upon Manco Inca, Hernando Pizarro led his men from Yucay to the Inca Citadel of Ollantaytambo. Google Earth.
The town of Ollantaytambo sits below the Citadel at 9,100 feet. Hernando Pizarro and his men suffered a defeat at the Citadel by Manco Inca and his warriors. Courtesy of Wiki.
A city street with a water channel built by the Incas. Courtesy of WIKICOMMONS.
Another Ollantaytambo street scene. Courtesy of Edias.
The Citadel was an imposing collection of forts and storage areas. The steepness of the numerous walls of the several valleys made attacks by the Christians difficult to effect. Courtesy of Wiki.
One of the several forts within the boundaries of the Citadel. R. Villarreal Collection.
A row of stairs within the Citadel. R. Villarreal Collection.
Strange structures on the hill side. Courtesy of TicketMachu.
Terraces viewed from and staircase. R. Villarreal Collection.
Another stairwell. R. Villarreal Collection.

After Manco Inca and his generals killed hundreds of Spaniards, Francisco Pizarro sent urgent requests to Panamá for reinforcements. Licentiate Gaspar de Espinosa hired three hundred men and Captain Pastene sailed them to Peru on the Santiaguillo, Consolación, and San Sebastián. Here, Pastene sends men ashore for water. Artist: Geoffrey Ingleton.
The Consolación sailing at sunset. Artist: Robert Shore.
The Santiaguillo sails on over calm seas as the sun is reflected upon the waters. Artist: Yngve Berg.

On the dark and rainy night of April 8 of 1537, Marshal Almagro and some three hundred of his men entered Cusco, imprisoned Hernando and Gonzalo Pizarro, and declared the sacred city was his. Artist: Lopez de Gomara.

After his defeat at Calca, Manco Inca decided to retreat to the high jungle district of Vilcabamba, seventy miles WNW from Cusco. There, In Vitcos, the remains of a previous civilization covered the countryside. This is one of the areas containing structural remnants. Courtesy of GOPERU.

Prior to the Battle of Abancay, Marshal Almagro sent his son, Diego de Almagro II, known as \"Diegito\", to Alonso de Alvarado to negotiate a truce. De Alvarado held the young man as a prisoner. Artist: Everett Gee Jackson.

Prior to negotiating a truce with Marquess Pizarro at Mala, Marshal Almagro and his men rode to the coast and, at today's Chincha, 120 miles south from Lima, began the construction of a town. Artist: E. Taylor.
Battle of Las Salinas. On April 26 of 1538, the forces of Hernando Pizarro defeated those of Diego de Almagro on the Las Salinas salt flats outside Cusco. Artist: Theodo de Bry.
An artist's rendition of the Battle at Las Salinas. Artist: Everett Gee Jackson.
An Earth image of the location of the Battle of Las Salinas.
On July 8 of 1538, Hernando Pizarro ordered the beheading of Marshal Diego de Almagro. Artist unknown.
In August of 1540, Marquess Pizarro sent his brother, Gonzalo, in search of the Land of Cinnamon and the golden Land of El Dorado. Artist: Unknown.
The Marquess Pizarro hears rumors of his assassination but does not believe them. Artist: Lima de Freitas.
On Sunday, 26 June of 1541, the followers of Almagro the Lad charge through the Lima streets on their way to kill the Marquess. Artist: Edward Bawden.
The men of Chile exact their vengeance upon Francisco Pizarro at his home. Artist: Unknown.
The Licentiate Vaca de Castro was sent by the Crown to restore order to Peru after the executions of Diego de Almagro and Francisco Pizarro. Artist unknown.
Vaca de Castro led Spanish forces in the defeat of Almagro the Lad at the Battle of Chupas on 16 September of 1542. Artist unknown.
Father Bartolomé de las Casas, the Protector of the Indians, wrote the book \"The Destruction of the Indies\" about the abuses of Indians in the New World. Artist: Unknown.
An idealized rendering of de las Casas. Artist: Felix Parra.
An Earth image of Quito, with the battlefield of Iñaquito to the north. In this battle, Pizarro defeated the Viceroy, Blasco Vela.

Blasco Vela marched through Quito on his way north to link with Captain Belalcázar for reinforcements. He passed through Pasto, Colombia seen here. In 1982, the author and his wife traveled to this city to adopt their second daughter. Courtesy of JORGELRM.
Gonzalo Pizarro chose the place of battle on a small plain called Iñaquito, here depicted. Artist: I Riquelme.
Photo of the neighborhood of Iñaquito. Most of its inhabitants are Americans! Courtesy of H3ktor.
After the victory at Iñaquito, Gonzalo Pizarro enters Lima. Artist: Edward Bawden.
Another depiction of Pizarro entering Lima. Artist: Everett Gee Jackson.
The Santiaguillo sails south with the new President, Pedro de la Gasca, on board. Artist: Gordon Grant.
The top men furl the main sail before the storm strikes. Artist: Gordon Grant.
The Santiaguillo sails the heavy seas. Artist: Millard Sheets.
The Consolación takes on a wave bow on. Artist: Gordon Grant.
The Consolación struggles in the heavy seas. Artist: Hans Alexander Mueller.
The Consolación in calmer seas. Artist: Hans Alexander Mueller.
Father Pedro de la Gasca, the new President of Spanish lands in the New World. Artist: Everett Gee Jackson.
Another rendering of President de la Gasca. Artist: Valentin Carderera y Solano.
The forces of Pedro de la Gasca were defeated by Gonzalo Pizarro and his army at the Battle of Huarina on the eastern shores of Lake Titicaca. Earth image.
This is the flat plains near Huarina where the battle took place. Courtesy of J. Ascot.

After obtaining reinforcements, de la Gasca decided to march to Cusco to give battle to Gonzalo.  They crossed the Abancay river at a place near this bridge that dates from the mid-18th century. Courtesy of Saul Abelardo.
On their way to Cusco, de la Gasca and his men passed through Cotabamba. There are several staircases like this one in the town. Courtesy of Beams.
Past Cotabamba the land descends to the Apurimac river. On the opposite side are steep cliffs that here are mounted by a road with 24 curves. Earth image.
This is the location of the Battle of Xaquixahuana (today's Anta), where most of Gonzalo Pizarro's army deserted him. Earth image.
Today's small town of Anta. It's surrounded by crop growing plantations for the Cusco region. Courtesy of Edwin Noha.
A stylized depiction of the Battle of Xaquixahuana. Pizarro and de Carbajál were beheaded after the Battle and their heads displayed in Lima. Artist unknown.

The severed heads of Francisco de Carbajál and Gonzalo Pizarro were hung in the main square of Lima. The text reads: \"These are the heads of the traitors, Francisco de Carbajál and Gonzalo Pizarro, who rebelled in Peru against their Sovereign, and battled in the cause of treason against the royal standard on the plain of Xaquixahuana on the 9th of April of 1548.\" Artist: Everett Gee Jackson.
